Davenport, [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1979|3|28|1923|1|7|mf=y}}
[[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Memphis blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]], [[musician]] | years_active = Early 1940s–1981 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Joe Willie Wilkins''' (January 7, 1923O'Neal, Jim: Joe Willie Wilkins - 1923-1979.- ''[[Living Blues]]'' 42 (January/February 1979), pp. 8-9 – March 28, 1979)Huggins, Cilla: Joe Willie Wilkins obituary.- ''[[Blues Unlimited]]'' 134 (March/June 1979), pp. 12-13O'Neal, Jim: Joe Willie Wilkins - 1923-1979.- ''Living Blues'' 42 (January/February 1979), pp. 8-9 was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p138134/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Joe Willie Wilkins|author=Chadbourne, Eugene|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=August 27, 2010}} Whilst he influenced contemporaries such as [[Houston Stackhouse]], [[Robert Nighthawk]], [[David Honeyboy Edwards]], and [[Jimmy Rogers]],{{cite book | first= Fred J. | last= Hay | year= 2001 | title= Goin' Back to Sweet Memphis:Conversations weith the blues | edition= 1st | publisher= The University of Georgia Press | location= Athens, Georgia | isbn= 978-0-8203-2732-7 | page= 198}} Wilkins' bigger impact was on up and coming guitarists, including [[Little Milton]], [[B.B. King]], and [[Albert King]]. Wilkins' songs included "Hard Headed Woman" and "It's Too Bad." ==Biography== Wilkins was born in Davenport, [[Coahoma County, Mississippi|Coahoma County]], [[Mississippi]]. He grew up on a [[plantation]] near [[Bobo, Coahoma County, Mississippi|Bobo]]. His father, Papa Frank Wilkins, was a local [[sharecropper]] and [[guitarist]], whose friend was the [[country blues]]man, [[Charlie Patton|Charley Patton]]. Young Wilkins learned to play guitar, [[harmonica]] and [[accordion]]. His early proficiency of the guitar, and slavish devotion to learning from [[Gramophone record|records]], earned him the [[nickname]] of "Walking Seeburg" ([[Seeburg Corporation]] being an early manufacturer of [[jukebox]]). Becoming a well-known musician in the [[Mississippi Delta]], by the early 1940s Wilkins took over from [[Robert Lockwood, Jr.]] in [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]]'s band. In 1941, Wilkins reloacted to [[Helena, Arkansas]], and joined both Williamson and Lockwood on [[KFFA (AM)|KFFA]] Radio's "[[King Biscuit Time]]".{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Oliver | year= 1969 | title= The Story of the Blues | edition= 2nd | publisher= Northeastern University Press | location= Massachusetts | isbn= 978-0712674928 | page= 171}} Through the 1940s Wilkins broadcast regularly playing alongside Williamson, [[Willie Love]], [[Robert Nighthawk]], [[Elmore James]], [[Memphis Slim]], [[Houston Stackhouse]] and [[Howlin' Wolf]]. His guitar playing appeared on several [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] by Williamson, Love and [[Big Joe Williams]], for the latter of whom he played [[bass guitar|bass]]. For [[Muddy Waters]], Wilkins was noted as the first guitarist from the Delta who played single string guitar riffs without a slide. Later on, Muddy Waters stated {{cquote|"The man is great, the man is stone great. For blues, like I say, he's the best."}} Forming The Three Aces with [[Willie Nix]] and Love in 1950, he rejoined Williamson at [[KWEM Radio]], which led on to Wilkin's becoming part of the [[recording studio|studio]] band at [[Sun Records]]. He was also utilised by [[Trumpet Records]], and as a prominent sideman, Wilkins recorded with Williamson, Love, Nix, [[Arthur Crudup|Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup]], [[Roosevelt Sykes]], [[Big Walter Horton]], [[Little Walter]], [[Mose Vinson]], [[Joe Hill Louis]], [[Elmore James]], and [[Floyd Jones]]. [[Charley Booker]]'s final recording was as a guest with Wilkins at a 1973 blues festival at [[Notre Dame, Indiana|Notre Dame]] in [[South Bend, Indiana]].O'Neal, Jim (2003): "Greenville, Mississippi". In ''The Modern Downhome blues Sessions Vol 1: Arkansas & Mississippi 1951-1952'' [CD Booklet]. London: Ace Records, pp. 11-12 The same year, [[Mimosa Records]] released a [[single (music)|single]] of Wilkin's debut vocal performance. Adamo Records later issued a [[live album]] of some of his concert dates. His working relationship and friendship with Houston Stackhouse endured over the years, with Stackhouse at one time living in the same premises as Wilkins and his wife. Wilkins and Stackhouse played at various blues [[music festival]]s, and were part of the traveling Memphis Blues Caravan.{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=4329|title=Houston Stackhouse (1910–1980) |author=Harris, Jeff |publisher=Encyclopediaofarkansas.net |accessdate=August 27, 2010}} After undergoing a [[colostomy]] in the late 1970s, Wilkins still continued to perform.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p138134|pure_url=yes}}|title=Joe Willie Wilkins |author=Chadbourne, Eugene |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=August 27, 2010}} Wilkins is buried near Memphis in the Galilee Memorial Gardens.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/delta/blues/people/joewillie_wilkins.htm |title=Trail of the Hellhound: Joe Willie Wilkins |publisher=Nps.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==Confusion over dates== There is some confusion over both the precise date of birth, and death, for Wilkins. Various sources quote 1921 or 1922 as his year of birth, and some cite 1981 for his death. In the latter respect [[Allmusic]] erroneously stated "his final performances were an East Coast tour in 1981, and he died in the week following these engagements. ==Songwriting== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Song title !Recorded by |- |"Hard Headed Woman" |Various artists - ''Memphis Blues Caravan - Vol. 2'' |- |"Leave Me Alone" |P.J. Colt |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/joe-willie-wilkins-mn0000213691/songs |title=Joe Willie Wilkins | Songs |publisher=AllMusic |date=1923-01-07 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==See also== *[[List of Memphis blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.wirz.de/music/wilkinsjw.htm Illustrated Joe Willie Wilkins discography] {{Authority control|VIAF=71164122}} {{Persondata | NAME = Wilkins, Joe Willie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]] | DATE OF BIRTH = January 7, 1921 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Davenport, [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = March 28, 1979 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Memphis, Tennessee]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilkins, Joe Willie}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Mississippi]] [[Category:American session musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:Musicians from Tennessee]] [[Category:Memphis blues musicians]] [[Category:People from Coahoma County, Mississippi]] [[Category:People from Memphis, Tennessee]]
